image.altText: Troops stand scattered alone a dirt road.

items.synopsis: Israeli's Defence Minister tells troops gathered at the Gaza border they would soon see the Palestinian enclave "from inside", suggesting an expected ground invasion could be nearing. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli defence chief says troops will soon see Gaza 'from inside'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden's visit to Israel on Wednesday produced a heaping dose of vocal support, a deal to get limited humanitarian aid into Gaza from Egypt (likely by the end of the week) and a plea for Israelis not to allow rage over the deadly Hamas attack to consume them. "I understand. Many Americans understand," Biden said as he wrapped up his stay in Tel Aviv, likening the October 7 Hamas terror attack to the attacks against the United States on September 11, 2001, that killed nearly 3,000 people. "You can't look at what has happened here … and not scream out for justice," he said. "But I caution this: While you feel that rage, don't be consumed by it. "After 9/11, we were enraged in the United States. And while we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden wraps up Israel visit with a warning against being 'consumed' by rage

props.alt: Biden sits in front of Israeli and US flags.

children.content: Joe Biden.
(AP: Miriam Alster/pool)
US President
Joe Biden's

visit to Israel on Wednesday produced a heaping dose of vocal support, a deal to get limited humanitarian aid into Gaza from Egypt (likely by the end of the week) and a plea for Israelis not to allow rage over the deadly Hamas attack to consume them.

"I understand. Many Americans understand," Biden said as he wrapped up his stay in Tel Aviv, likening the October 7 Hamas terror attack to the attacks against the United States on September 11, 2001, that killed nearly 3,000 people.
"You can't look at what has happened here … and not scream out for justice," he said.
"But I caution this:
While you feel that rage, don't be consumed by it.
"After 9/11, we were enraged in the United States.
And while we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Heightened tensions around the world have prompted the American government to issue a Worldwide Caution Security Alert for its citizens overseas. The rare State Department alert says: "Due to increased tensions in various locations around the world, the potential for terrorist attacks, demonstrations or violent actions against US citizens and interests, the Department of State advises US citizens overseas to exercise increased caution ." It advises travelling Americans to stay alert in locations frequented by tourists, sign up for the Smart Traveler program and follow the State Department on social media. Earlier this week, the State Department warned Americans against travelling to Lebanon. The US embassy in its capital, Beirut, has been one of many Middle Eastern locations where demonstrations erupted after Tuesday's hospital blast in Gaza. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said there was "not necessarily any one thing" that had prompted the warning, "but everything that we're watching around the world".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US issues rare worldwide travel warning amid raised terror fears

children.content: Heightened tensions around the world have prompted the American government to issue a
Worldwide Caution Security Alert
for its citizens overseas.
The rare State Department alert says:
"Due to increased tensions in various locations around the world, the potential for terrorist attacks, demonstrations or violent actions against US citizens and interests, the Department of State
advises US citizens overseas to exercise increased caution
It advises travelling Americans to stay alert in locations frequented by tourists, sign up for the Smart Traveler program and follow the State Department on social media.
Earlier this week, the State Department warned Americans against travelling to Lebanon.
The US embassy in its capital, Beirut, has been one of many Middle Eastern locations where demonstrations erupted after Tuesday's hospital blast in Gaza.
State Department spokesman
Matthew Miller
said there was "not necessarily any one thing" that had prompted the warning, "but everything that we're watching around the world".

image.altText: A little girl looks through a fence

items.synopsis: With stockpiles of humanitarian aid backed up on one side, and desperate Palestinian civilians on the other, the world is waiting to see when the Rafah crossing between Egypt and the Gaza Strip could open. But it is proving a complicated problem to solve.

title.children: 'This is a red line': A tiny border crossing, millions of desperate Gazans, and a neighbour on the brink

image.altText: A woman standing at her kitchen bench with a sweet potato on a chopping board.

items.synopsis: To save money, Sara would cook a meal for her family and then fill up on two-minute noodles for herself. Then she was diagnosed with malnutrition. Experts say food insecurity is on the rise in Australia, but measuring the extent of the problem isn't easy.

title.children: Sara was skipping meals and eating instant noodles to save money. Then she was diagnosed with malnutrition

image.altText: The courtyard of a hospital with a crater in the brickwork.

items.synopsis: With Palestinian authorities claiming hundreds dead, many more injured and growing international outrage, the explosion at al-Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza demands examination and accountability.

title.children: Many rushed to condemn Israel for the Gaza hospital blast. But what does the evidence say?

image.altText: A woman is speaking at a podium and a man is standing next to her

items.synopsis: Sidney Powell pleads guilty to aiding the former US president's efforts to overturn his election defeat in the state of Georgia in 2020, agreeing to testify against him if called.

title.children: Former Trump lawyer Sidney Powell pleads guilty in Georgia election interference case

image.altText: An illustration of a crowd of people walking towards a court entrance wrapped in security fencing

items.synopsis: Lost hope and lives on hold — a flaw in Australia's asylum system allowed "bad actors" to exploit a legal loophole, and it's done more damage to asylum seekers searching for a better life.

title.children: How a legal loophole clogged courts and almost broke Australia's asylum seeker system

image.altText: Old dog fence

items.synopsis: Sheep graziers say the broken section is allowing feral animals to move freely between NSW and SA and threatening their industry, after long delays to repairs.

title.children: Big holes in 32km stretch of wild dog fence threatens livelihoods, graziers say

image.altText: Steelworks at dusk

items.synopsis: Authorities are investigating the loss of an industrial gauge with a radioactive source somewhere on a 1,000 hectare steelworks site on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula.

title.children: Authorities investigating after radioactive material goes missing at SA steelworks

image.altText: A man and woman in wedding dress getting married.

items.synopsis: Respite cottages give carers a break from looking after the person they care for but advocates say there's not enough, leaving many of Australia's 2.5 million unpaid carers at breaking point.

title.children: Overworked and lonely: Advocates say it's time Australia's more than 2.5 million unpaid carers got a break

image.altText: A blonde man looking upset

items.synopsis: Michael Charles Henley, 24, deliberately crashed into another car multiple times in Adelaide's south in 2021, killing a 20-year-old soon-to-be father. Today the 24-year-old was sentenced to 13 years and six months in prison, with a non-parole period of 11 years.

title.children: SA man who used 'vehicle as a weapon' sentenced over fatal crash

image.altText: Medicare

items.synopsis: You may have received a text or email in recent weeks from your GP asking you to register for something called MyMedicare. So how does the scheme work and is it worth signing up?

title.children: Have you been asked to sign up to MyMedicare? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair sits at a coffee shop with a book.

items.synopsis: Alcohol cost Frances her friends, family, and career. And on more than one occasion, it almost took her life.

title.children: Frances was told she'd be dead within months if she didn't stop drinking

image.altText: An aerial shot of a Melbourne suburb

items.synopsis: Victoria's independent infrastructure adviser says the state will be $43 billion better off if it swaps its urban sprawl for compact city living.

title.children: Infrastructure body warns housing in a 'sprawling city' would take up 12,000 MCGs in land

image.altText: A drone image of a road with three police officers standing to the side and a police car on the opposite side

items.synopsis: Police will prepare a report for the coroner and hand over the bones for reburial after radiocarbon dating revealed their age.

title.children: Human bones found near small town south of Adelaide likely ancient Aboriginal remains

image.altText: Dairy workers at a rally.

items.synopsis: Surging supermarket prices tell the story of why a wide range of dairy industry workers have mounted coordinated strike action this week. So where are these dairy profits going?

title.children: As the price of milk nearly doubles, why are its workers walking off the job?

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks into assembled microphones as Peter Dutton looks on.

items.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price was arguably one of the biggest winners from the referendum on a Voice to Parliament, but she faces an awkward truth back home, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price is one of the big winners from the referendum — but can she dodge the awkward questions?

image.altText: A police officer looks to the left of the photo

items.synopsis: SA Police announces it will publish details publicly of disciplinary proceedings against officers, following calls for mandatory proactive disclosure.

title.children: SA Police make details of officers' misconduct public for first time

image.altText: Photo of six Wiggles (including Emma as yellow wiggle) in skivvies at the triple j studio doing finger guns

items.synopsis: Hot Potato: The Story of The Wiggles traces the evolution of the beloved Australian children's entertainment group from "just four mates who made a record" to triple j hottest 100 winners.

title.children: One skivvy colour was everyone's last choice, plus other surprising insights from new Wiggles doco

image.altText: A man and a woman smiling at each other

items.synopsis: A controversial court decision makes it possible for Joko Widodo's son to run for vice-president. But is this all part of his plan to finally outmanoeuvre the woman who made him?

title.children: This all-powerful female party boss was behind Jokowi's rise. Will he betray her in his final hour?

image.altText: Stephen Edwards with parents David and Nelda

items.synopsis: An Tasmanian inquest hearing into the deaths of an elderly Hobart couple in 2016 comes to an abrupt end when a hand gesture from a witness towards the coroner sees the plug pulled on the video link from Queensland.

title.children: Coroner terminates witness's videolink after hand gesture during inquest into deaths of elderly couple

image.altText: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speakling alongside Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

items.synopsis: Rishi Sunak followed in the footsteps of US President Joe Biden, travelling to Israel to pledge support for the country in the war against Hamas.

title.children: British PM Sunak follows Biden to Israel to show support 'in darkest hour'

image.altText: Tim Mathieson wearing sunglasses

items.synopsis: The 66-year-old will be fined $7,000 after he formally pleaded guilty over the March 2022 incident.

title.children: Tim Mathieson, former partner of Julia Gillard, spared jail over sexual assault on sleeping woman

image.altText: close up of Perth's Children Hospital sign illuminated at night

items.synopsis: A healthcare worker who was working at Perth Children's Hospital (PCH) at the time a 13-year-old girl was allegedly raped claims the hospital's mental health ward remains unsafe despite state government assurances to the contrary.

title.children: Hospital ward where teenage girl was allegedly raped 'still not safe', insider says

image.altText: Lisa Wilkinson on stage at the 2022 Logie Awards.

items.synopsis: Journalist Lisa Wilkinson is suing Network Ten for legal costs that have been racked up fighting the defamation case brought against her and the network by Bruce Lehrmann.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson suing Network Ten for $370,000 over legal bills for Bruce Lehrmann defamation case

image.altText: A large plume of smoke and fire over a country landscape.

items.synopsis: Farmers are assessing their losses after what has been described as a "firestorm" that tore through a rural area west of Kempsey earlier this week, claiming the life of a 56-year-old man.

title.children: Four homes confirmed lost as farmers count the cost of 'tragic' NSW fire

image.altText: Mary Massina smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: The former chief executive of the body charged with developing the site of a new AFL stadium on Hobart's waterfront was paid $246,000 in "termination benefits" last year.

title.children: $246k 'termination' payout for Hobart Macquarie Point redevelopment boss who voluntarily resigned

image.altText: Man with glasses stands at front door smiling, holding a name badge reading Paul MacCartney CoHealth and a Beatles record

items.synopsis: When Paul MacCartney's parents named him, they thought The Beatles would fade into obscurity. Instead, they unknowingly condemned their son to a life of bad jokes and crossed wires.

title.children: Exclusive interview with Paul MacCartney: the Melbourne doctor who grew up in Sir Paul's shadow

image.altText: A tight head and shoulders shot of a Chinese woman wearing sunglasses with a stern look on her face, with a blurred background.

items.synopsis: QianQian Hu is jailed for three years for moving more than $2 million in cash from Perth to the eastern states, at the request of a person known only as "Lovely Girl", as part of a huge cocaine deal.

title.children: Woman jailed for role in Australia's biggest drug bust after $2m cash seizure

image.altText: Three young men throw stones towards soldiers using riot shields to form a blockade during a demonstration.

items.synopsis: Smartraveller, which is run by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), has changed the travel advice to Lebanon to "do not travel", citing the "volatile security situation".

title.children: 'Deeply concerned': Australians urged not to travel to Lebanon due to Israel-Gaza conflict

image.altText: Two women hold each other while one cries

items.synopsis: Markyia Major, 17, has not been seen since he ran into a relative's Yarrabah home, near Cairns, on August 27. Police have said they have grave concerns.

title.children: Family 'crying out for answers' pleads for information about teen boy missing for nearly two months

image.altText: The Milky Way Galaxy of stars stretches across a dark night sky, with a large shed and water tank in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Stargazers will be setting their alarms early this weekend to see the Orionids shower the sky in streaks of light as Earth passes through debris left by Halley's Comet.

title.children: Where's the best place to see the Orionid meteor shower?
